title: SpaceX test-fires crew rocket as teams monitor downrange abort zone weather
summary: SpaceX test-fired a Falcon 9 rocket at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center early Thursday, checking off another box on the pre-flight checklist before liftoff Sunday with a four-person crew heading for the International Space Station. But a weather forecast shows a high risk that winds or waves int the Atlantic Ocean could force a launch delay.

title: NASA’s Juno: Science Results Offer First 3D View of Jupiter Atmosphere
summary: New findings from NASA’s Juno probe orbiting Jupiter provide a fuller picture of how the planet’s distinctive and colorful atmospheric features offer clues about the unseen processes below its clouds.

title: DoD space agency changes course on satellite procurement in wake of Maxar’s protest
summary: In response to a protest filed by Maxar Technologies, the Defense Department’s Space Development Agency is canceling a solicitation issued Aug. 30 seeking bids for 144 satellites and will start over with a new procurement.

title: Hyten blasts ‘unbelievably’ slow DoD bureaucracy as China advances space weapons
summary: Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. John Hyten warned that bureaucratic inertia and fear of failing are thwarting innovation in the Department of Defense while China continues to roll out new military and space technologies.

title: CASIS and Estée Lauder seek microgravity research on plastic alternatives
summary: The Center for the Advancement of Science in Space (CASIS) announced plans Oct. 28 to work with multinational corporation Estée Lauder to solicit microgravity projects aimed at reducing plastics waste.

title: NASA to Host Briefing on Webb Telescope Engineering, Deployments
summary: NASA will hold a virtual media briefing 11 a.m. EDT Tuesday, Nov. 2, to discuss the engineering of the James Webb Space Telescope, the world’s largest and most powerful space science telescope.

title: A once-quiet battle to replace the space station suddenly is red hot
summary: Three competitors have already entered the arena. More are expected.

title: JWST launch preparations on track
summary: The success of the most recent Ariane 5 launch has allowed preparations for the launch of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope to move into the home stretch, officials said Oct. 27.

title: SpaceX rideshare program beats small rockets for Emirati launch contract
summary: The United Arab Emirates’ (UAE) space agency has contracted with SpaceX to launch a domestically-built Earth observation satellite on a Falcon 9...

title: Russia launches supply ship on two-day trip to space station
summary: A Russian Progress cargo freighter loaded with more than 5,000 pounds of crew supplies, fuel, water, and air lifted off Wednesday from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan and rode a Soyuz launcher into orbit on the first leg of a two-day trip to the International Space Station.

updatedAt.title: Russian cargo freighter docks with International Space Station
updatedAt.summary: Two days after launching from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, a Russian Progress cargo freighter autonomously docked with the International Space Station Friday to deliver nearly three tons of fuel, food, and other supplies for the lab’s seven-person crew.

updatedAt.title: Space Development Agency’s request for bids challenged for ‘risk’ imposed on contractors
updatedAt.summary: Maxar Technologies decided to challenge a Defense Department procurement of 126 satellites because of the financial burden the program imposed on contractors, the company said.

updatedAt.title: Exodus Orbitals pivots to satellite leasing model after launch delay
updatedAt.summary: Exodus Orbitals, a startup developing software enabling customers to upload and run applications from orbit, is in talks about leasing satellites as plans to launch its own are delayed seven months to October 2022.

updatedAt.title: NASA, National Geographic Partner to Show Inside Artemis Moon Mission
updatedAt.summary: NASA has selected National Geographic to help tell the story of Artemis II, the first Artemis flight that will carry astronauts around the Moon and back to Earth aboard the agency’s Orion spacecraft.

updatedAt.title: Ariane 6 undergoing preparations for its 2022 debut
updatedAt.summary: ArianeGroup and the European Space Agency are carrying out preparations for the maiden launch of the Ariane 6 rocket next year. Ariane 6 represents the next generation of the Ariane family of rockets, intended to allow its customers lower-cost access to space. The rocket and launch pad still have an extensive test program ahead of them, with a current target launch date in the second half of 2022.

updatedAt.title: Honda has already developed a prototype engine for a rocket
updatedAt.summary: "We believe that we have made huge progress in this development."

updatedAt.title: Rocket Report: Russia finally agrees to fly SpaceX, Firefly targets early 2022
updatedAt.summary: "From our viewpoint, SpaceX has gained sufficient experience."

updatedAt.title: SpaceX preparing Super Heavy, Starbase for booster’s next steps
updatedAt.summary: Amid a flurry of deliveries and work on several new Starship boosters, SpaceX is preparing the first truly finished Super Heavy for...

updatedAt.title: Revised budget reconciliation package reduces NASA infrastructure funds
updatedAt.summary: A new, scaled-back version of a spending package released Oct. 28 sharply reduced the money allocated to NASA infrastructure and climate change projects, while continuing to exclude funding for a second Artemis lunar lander.

updatedAt.title: Terran Orbital plans to go public through SPAC merger
updatedAt.summary: Terran Orbital, the parent company of Tyvak and PredaSAR, announced plans Oct. 28 to go public through a merger with a special-purpose acquisition company.
